bibl.title: Minutes of the Annual Meeting, Board of Managers, Walter Reed Memorial Association, Washington, D.C., November 15, 1948

div1.p: The Walter Reed Memorial Association Board expresses regret to [Laura Armistead Carter] Stitt upon the death of her husband, Board member E.R. Stitt. The Board reviews the plan to place a plaque in the building where Reed died and sets a tentative date for Hench and Truby to install the plaque. Board members agree to raise monthly support of Mrs. Reed by $50.00.

div1.head: Minutes of the Annual Meeting, Board of Managers, Walter Reed Memorial Association, Washington, D.C., November 15, 1948
div1.p:
ANNUAL MEETING, BOARD OF MANAGERS, WALTER REED MEMORIAL ASSOCIATION
Washington, D.C., November 15, 1948

The Board met at 10:30 A.M., in the Board Room, American Security & Trust Company,
15th and Pennsylvania Avenue, Northwest, and was called to order by its President,
Brig. Gen. Jefferson R. Kean, U.S.A., Retired.

PRESENT: Brig. Gen. J. R. Kean, President; Dr. Gilbert Grosvenor; Brig. Gen. F. R.
Keefer; Brig. Gen. Albert G. Love; Mr. Hans W. Ireland, Treasurer: and Col. Joseph F.
Siler, Secretary. Maj. Gen. M. W. Ireland, though absent, had authorized Col. Siler
to act for him. (Proxy on file.)

ABSENT: Maj. Gen. C. R. Reynolds; Dr. Philip S. Hench (in Europe); Dr. L. O. Howard;
Rear Adm. E. R. Stitt (deceased); and Maj. Gen. Raymond W. Bliss, Surgeon General, U.
S. Army. Col. Siler stated that subsequent to the last annual meeting when the Surgeon
General of the Army was made ad additional member of the Board, through an oversight,
he had failed to add the name of the Surgeon General (Maj. Gen. Bliss) to the mailing
list of the members of the Board, and as a result he greatly regretted that notice of
the annual meeting had not been amiled to General Bliss.

The Treasurer submitted the following report, summarizing comparative income and
disbursement for the fiscal years ending October 31, 1947 and October 31, 1948, and
the par and market values of capital investments for like periods of time.

div1.p:
The members of the Board were informed that Rear Admiral E. R. Stitt, an outstand-
ing member of the Board for many years, had died two days previously, on November 13,
1948. All members of the Board expressed their very deep regret and requested that the
President of the Board write Mrs. Stitt expressing their heartfelt sympathy. (A copy
of the letter sent Mrs. Stitt is attached to these minutes as Exhibit B.)

Consideration was given to the election of a member to fill the vacancy caused
by the death of Rear Admiral Stitt. After some discussion of various possibilities,
Dr. Fred L. Soper, Director, Pan American Sanitary Bureau, was elected to fill the
vacancy.

Colonel Siler stated that the members of the Board would recall that at the annual
meeting last year Dr. Hench had told them that he and General Truby recently had
visited Fort Lesley J. Mc Nair (formerly Washington Barracks) for the purpose of locat-
ing the building and room in which Walter Reed had died. They found that the former
hospital building had been converted into apartments and that changes in inside parti-
tions had resulted in some changes in the room. Dr. Hench recommended that the Board
arrange to place a plaque or plaques in the building to indicate that date of the death
of Walter Reed and other pertinent data.

This plan was approved by the Board. It was known that both Dr. Hench and General
Truby probably would be in Washington in May, 1948. for the purpose of attending memo-
rial exercises for Walter Reed to be held as a special feature of the Fourth Inter-
national Congresses on Tropical Medicine and Malaria, and Col. Siler anticipated that
he could arrange, at that time, for Dr. Hench, Gen. Truby and himself to visit Ft.
Lesley J. Mc Nair, consult with the Commanding General and complete arrangements for
installation of the plaques. Unfortunately, Dr. Hench was in Washington too short a
time to permit the tentative plan to be carried out. Dr. Hench will return from Europe
in December, 1948, and it is hoped that he will visit Washington during the next four
or five months, in which case the final plans for installation of the plaques will be
completed.

Col. Siler informed members of the Board that, recently, he had seen Mrs. Reed's
daughter when she was on a short visit to her borther, General Reed, and had learned
something of Mrs. Walter Reed's condition. She is now 93 years of age, has been bed-
ridden for the past two years, is gradually losing ground physically and has to have
constant nursing care. Mrs. Reed's income for the past few years has been approximately
$315.00 per month (Government pension $125.00, anonymous donor $100.00. Walter Reed
Memorial Association $90.00) and Col. Siler gained the definite impression that with
recent increases in cost of living and expenses incident to nursing care, Mrs. Reed's
daughter was experiencing great difficulty in “making ends meet”. To meet the exist-
ing situation, upon motion duly made and seconded, the following resolution was passed.

RESOLVED, That the Treasurer of this Association be, and he hereby is, authorized
to increase the monthly payments to Mrs. Emily L. Reed fifty dollars ($50.00) per
month, beginning December 1, 1948 and continuing for not more than twelve months: and
further, should the income of the Association not be sufficient to make this payment,
that the Treasurer be, and he hereby is, authorized to sell sufficient of the capital
assets to make such payments.
There being no further business, the meeting was adjourned.
